column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0055] In one embodiment, control system 110 may send commands to multiple components (e.g., 120-1 to 120-N) to concurrently perform diagnostic processes for these components.
#Text=Accordingly, control system 110 may be configured to multi-task the diagnosis of the operations of multiple systems (e.g., 200) that operate within a work machine.
#Text=Alternatively, control system 110 may be configured to test multiple systems sequentially.
#Text=For example, in one embodiment, control system 110 may send command signals to 120-1 to 120-N in sequential order.
#Text=System 110 may diagnose signals from sensors 130-1 to 135-N in the order responses from these sensors are received.
#Text=Alternatively, control system 110 may analyze sensor signal outputs in the order the command signals are sent (e.g., analyze sensor 135-1, then sensor 135-2, and so on).
#Text=[0056] In another embodiment, control system 210 may be configured to send a broadcast message to multiple components 120-1 to 120-N over data link 105.

#Text=This embodiment may be applicable where the multiple components 120-1 to 120-N are of similar types (e.g., motor drive systems that have similar operating specifics, such as multiple fluid pump systems, etc.).

#Text=[0057] In yet another embodiment, the processes performed by the control system 210 consistent with certain aspects related to the present invention may be embedded within a component (e.g., 220).
#Text=Accordingly, component 220 may initiate the periodic testing of a sub-component 230.
#Text=For example, control unit 222 may execute a test process that periodically produces control signals to adjust the operation of motor 224.
#Text=Further, component 220 may be configured to receive the signal produced by sensor 235.
#Text=Based on the received signal, control unit 222 may perform a diagnostic process similar to that described in connection with FIGS. 5 and 6.

#Text=In such an embodiment, component 220 may perform fault locating processes that analyze communication paths, sensors, and hardware and software elements associated with its operation and that of sub-component 230.
#Text=Based on the results of its analysis, control unit 222 may generate a fault message in a manner similar to that performed with respect to Step 570 of FIG. 5.
#Text=Alternatively, control unit 222 may provide the results of its diagnosis processes to control system 210 for further analysis and/or generation of a fault message.
#Text=Additionally, control system 210 may use the results of the diagnostics performed by control unit 222 to initiate its own diagnostic process.
#Text=The results of this process may be compared by control system 210 to the results provided by control unit 222 to provide a redundant test process to decrease fault reporting errors.

#Text=[0058] In another embodiment, along the same lines as the exemplary embodiment described in the previous paragraph, when control unit 222 adjusts the operation of motor 224, it may send a message to control unit 220 over data link 205 indicating that a test process is in progress.
#Text=Based on this message, control system 210 may collect any subsequently received signals from sensor 235 and perform the diagnostic process explained above with respect to FIGS. 5 and 6.

#Text=Alternatively, control system 210 may be configured to wait a predetermined period of time after receiving the test in progress message from control unit 222 before beginning the diagnostic process.
#Text=[0059] The use of a multi-component command signal may have notable benefits.
#Text=For example, to gain more information about the operation of a system, the response of the system may be observed with respect to each of the components of the command.

#Text=For example, if a DC component of a command corresponds to an expected motor speed of 100 rpm, then the speed of the motor may be monitored after issuing the command to determine whether the motor is, indeed, operating at the expected rate.
#Text=This information, however, may not indicate whether or not the sensor is operating properly.

#Text=In order to gain more information about the system, including whether the appropriate sensors are functioning properly, a time-varying component of the command may be superimposed on the DC component of the command.
#Text=In response to the time-varying component, the motor speed, for example, would be expected to exhibit a corresponding variation over time.
#Text=If such a time-varying response is measured, then this information would confirm that both the motor and the sensor are functioning as expected.
